name: Shaam-e-Sarhad Village Resort

reviews.text: I went this hotel with a friend and my son who is only 15 months for two nights. I wanted to book a bungas, but they were full while we were there,so we stayed in a tent. The place located in rural area of hodka village. I was bit scared of snake, as someone mentioned on tripadvisor. But we did not see any snakes.
reviews.title: unique place

reviews.text: The place is quite big. there are two outside shops and opendoor restaurants and sofa area. There was local tribe music concert every night. The shops were not bad. Their price was better than outside of hotel.
reviews.title: Be sure to stay in a bhunga!

reviews.text: When I went inside tent, I smelled a bit, but I did not mind too much. The decoration is very pretty and toilet and bath were fine. The hot water is only available few hours in the morning. My son enjoyed and I did not find difficult to stay there with my son. I also saw a couple of pretty old ladies there.
reviews.title: Beauty in desert

reviews.text: Food in the hotel is included. Food was quite nice. (all veg) They also have mineral water which they charge. But it was not expensive.(20 rupees per bottle)
reviews.title: Fantastic hospitality and a unique experience

reviews.text: We visited Hodka village and around. I went there for shopping, but it was not really cheap, as they have so many tourists. They are over priced. But I really enjoyed great rann which is such a unique place in the world. It was very quite,...sound of wind.
reviews.title: Enchanting Kutch

reviews.text: What a wonderful and "real" experience. Although, I believe the term "resort" is misleading. This is a wonderful oasis in the desert - near the village of Hodka. The village is walled - and contains three bungas (wonderfully elaborate mud huts) and 12 tents. Each has it's own bathing facility. There is a central eating area where you are served three meals a day (all vegetarian). In the evenings local people come and dance/sing/play instruments for guest's enjoyment (when there are guests at the resort - I was there almost alone two nights, hence no entertainment). I greatly enjoyed this experience and used this resort as my daily jumping off point to visit local more remote villages closer to the Pakistan border - to visit local artisans. I made my overall arrangements through a group called "Indian Moments" - and told them I wanted a more "real" experience than a hotel stay.
reviews.title: Great way to learn about rural India's way of life

likes.liked: — a chance to stay in a mud hut and truly experience the way folks in rural India live on a daily basis
likes.disliked: — large black snakes in the area kept me from wanting to leave my doors open at night!

description: Visitors: Shaam-E-Sarhad is an eco-resort built in a Kutchi village-style setting using locally sourced materials and crafts of the region. It is owned and managed by the Hodka village community and is open only from October to March. The resort promotes Endogenous Tourism where one travels not just for pleasure, but also to appreciate local community and their life in rural Gujarat. "The Endogenous Tourism Project in Hodka village seeks to promote local culture and craft based tourism for sustainable livelihoods and integrated rural development. Its aim is to improve the local people's quality of life, by creating more livelihood options, while preserving and allowing the community to develop their unique culture and share it with visitor."~ The use of local architectural style, the intricate art & crafts is very evident as soon as one enters Shaam-E-Sarhad (translated 'Sunset at the border'). Hodka village is not very far from the Rann of Kutch region which shares the border with Pakistan.
